sa13.25:1.2: One time, the Buddha was staying at Anāthapiṇḍada Park in Jeta Grove in Śrāvastī.
sa13.25:2.1: It was then that the Bhagavān addressed the monks,
sa13.25:2.2: “You must part with wrong views; you must stop wrong views.
sa13.25:2.3: If stopping wrong views wasn’t possible, then I would never say that you must part with and stop wrong views.
sa13.25:2.4: It’s because wrong views can be stopped that I say a monk should part with wrong views.
sa13.25:2.5: If he doesn’t part with wrong views, then wrong views will make him undertake what’s aimless, unbeneficial, and painful.
sa13.25:2.6: I therefore say you must part with wrong views.
sa13.25:2.7: I also say this of wrong intention, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, and wrong concentration.
sa13.25:3.1: “Monks, after you part with wrong views, you must cultivate right views.
sa13.25:3.2: If cultivating right views wasn’t possible, I would never say that you must cultivate right views.
sa13.25:3.3: It’s because right views can be cultivated that I say a monk must cultivate right views.
sa13.25:3.4: If he doesn’t cultivate right views, he will undertake what’s aimless, unbeneficial, and painful.
sa13.25:3.5: Because not cultivating right views undertakes what’s aimless, unbeneficial, and painful, I therefore say he must cultivate right views.
sa13.25:3.6: Because they are purposeful and beneficial, he’ll always attain well-being.
sa13.25:3.7: Therefore, monks, you must cultivate right views.
sa13.25:3.8: I also say this of right intention, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right concentration.”
sa13.25:4.1: After the Buddha taught this sutra, the monks who heard what he taught rejoiced and handed it down.
